playn.core

Class Game.Default

  • java.lang.Object
    • playn.core.Game.Default
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Game
    Enclosing interface:
    Game

    public abstract static class Game.Default
extends Object
implements Game
    An implementation of Game that separates game processing into two phases: simulation and interpolation. The simulation phase takes place in update(int) and is called with a monotonoically increasing timer at a fixed rate. The interpolation phase takes place in paint(float) and is called every time the game is rendered to the display (which may be more frequently than the simulation is updated). The interpolation phase will generally interpolate the values computed in update(int) to provide smooth rendering based on lower-frequency simulation updates.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Game.Default

        public Game.Default(int updateRate)
        Creates an instance of the default game implementation.
        Parameters:
        updateRate - the desired update rate of the main game loop, in ms.

    • Method Detail

      • update

        public void update(int delta)
        Called when at least updateRate ms have elapsed since the last update call. Input-handling, physics, and game logic should be performed in this method. It is also appropriate to update the structure of the scene graph here (adding, removing layers). You should not animate scene graph properties in update; that should happen in paint(float).
        Parameters:
        delta - time (in ms) since the last update call. This will always be updateRate, unless the game is running slowly. In that case, multiple update calls will be coalesced into a single update call and delta will be a multiple of updateRate. Your game should decide at that point whether to run one simulation update with a larger time interval, or to run multiple simulation updates with the standard interval. Beware that if your update calculations take longer than updateRate to complete then your game loop will fall further and further behind and will eventually fail. Choose a long enough update interval to accommodate your processing.

      • paint

        public void paint(float alpha)
        Called every time the backend refreshes the display (usually 60 times per second). Any manual painting (e.g. Surface.drawImage(playn.core.Image, float, float)) should be performed in this method. Animating of scene graph elements (smoothly updating an element's transform or alpha, for example) should also take place here. You should not run game logic in this method.
        Parameters:
        alpha - a value representing the fraction of time between the last call to update(int) and the next scheduled call. For example if the previous update was scheduled to happen at T=500ms and the next update at T=530ms (i.e. updateRate returns 30) and the actual time at which we are being rendered is T=517ms then alpha will be (517-500)/(530-500) or 17/30. This is usually between 0 and 1, but if your game is running slowly, it can exceed 1. For example, if an update is scheduled to happen at T=500ms and the update actually happens at T=517ms, and the update call itself takes 20ms, the alpha value passed to paint will be (537-500)/(530-500) or 37/30.

      • tick

        public void tick(int elapsed)
        Description copied from interface: Game
        Called on every frame tick, is responsible for performing all game logic and scene graph updates. When this method returns, the scene graph will be rendered to the screen.
        Specified by:
        tick in interface Game
        Parameters:
        elapsed - the number of ms that have elapsed since the game started.
